title: face masks matt hancock shops compulsory
story: The Health Secretary said he would be reviewing the wearing of face coverings in crowded places indoors to stop the spread of coronavirus.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHe said: The use of face coverings that are not formal face masks is valuable especially in some circumstances and therefore it’s mandated on public transport and it has been long recommended in some shops.A Department of Health source said that while Mr Hancock was not planning on issuing any immediate guidelines on wearing face masks in shops, the issue was being kept under constant review.It comes after the president of the Royal Society slammed the government for its confusing message on the use of face masks and coverings in the UK during the Covid- pandemic.At present, people in the UK have been urged to wear a face mask or covering when using public transport.This is while people have also been advised to wear masks when in supermarkets.Venki Ramakrishnan said other countries have managed to implement the use of face masks into their daily lives so there was no reason why the UK should not have implemented a more stringent policy.He said not wearing a mask should be seen as a social taboo and added that the message from the government had “not been clear enough”.“Perhaps people do not really understand the benefits or are not convinced of them. Whatever the reasons, we need to overcome our reservations and wear face coverings whenever we are around others in public.“It used to be quite normal to have quite a few drinks and drive home, and it also used to be normal to drive without seatbelts. Today, both of those would be considered antisocial, and not wearing face coverings in public should be regarded in the same way.”He said the use of masks lowers the chance of future surge and lockdowns which are “economically and psychologically disruptive”.His comments come after new research was released that detailed the effectiveness of the use of face masks and coverings.One study, by the Data Evaluation and Learning for Viral Epidemicsgroup said masks could reduce the risk of transmission and can also provide benefits to those who wear them.While another paper from the Royal Society’s Science in Emergencies Tasking Covid- group, highlighted how behind the UK was compared to other countries.It claims that in April the uptake of people wearing a mask in the UK was  per cent.It claimed that countries such as Italy had a . per cent uptick, while the US had . per cent and Spain had . per cent.Prof Ramakrishnan said masks need to be treated like any other item of clothing and added that we need to get used to wearing them.Speaking on BBC Radio ’s Today programme this week, he added: I think what we would like for the Government is to be a bit stronger and clearer about the messaging and require it whenever you are in crowded public spaces where you cannot get more than two metres away from the next person.If youre in a crowded setting, you ought to wear a mask.He said outdoors was less of a problem for transmission and that mask-wearing was largely required in indoor settings.Charities have also warned that there are exemptions to the rules and said that not everyone is physically able to wear a mask or covering.The government previously released guides on how to make coverings at home from old t-shirts.Downing Street stressed the need for people to wear face coverings properly, covering both the nose and mouth and a spokesperson for the Prime Minister said a wider roll out is always under reviewWe have been very clear about the benefits of people wearing face coverings.Face coverings can help us protect others and reduce the spread of the viruspeople are infected but not showing symptoms.Highlighting the correct way to wear a mask they added: Covid- is a respiratory disease. title: coronavirus airborne transmission spread infected droplets world health organisation
story: There is emerging evidence of Covid- airborne transmission in crowded, closed, poorly ventilated settings, an official said.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt comes after more than  scientists wrote an open letter to the agency urging officials to recognise the virus may be spread in the air.The WHO has maintained Covid is spread primarily through droplets from the nose or mouth, which are expelled via coughs, sneezes or speaking.In its latest update at the weekend, the Geneva-based agency said that airborne transmission is possible only after medical procedures that produce very small droplets.But following the open letter warning that officials are underestimating the risk of airborne spread, the WHO appears to have made a U-turn.Professor Benedetta Allegranzi, technical lead for infection prevention and control, said last night that the possibility could not be ruled out.If the evidence is confirmed, it could affect guidelines for social distancing indoors.Published in the Clinical Infectious Diseases journal, the letters signatories call on health officials to update guidance to include measures which would mitigate the risk of airborne transmission.The group of  experts outline studies which they say suggests coronavirus can spread through smaller particles that linger in the air.While hand washing and social distancing are appropriate, the signatories say these measures are insufficient in providing protection from virus-carrying respiratory microdroplets released into the air by those with Covid-.According to the group, measures that should be taken include providing sufficient ventilation, to minimise recirculating air, and avoiding overcrowding, particularly on public transport.  When asked about the letter during a press briefing on Tuesday, Prof Allegranzi said officials had been in discussions with the letters signatories.We acknowledge that there is emerging evidence in this field, as in all other fields, regarding the Covid- virus and pandemic, she told reporters.And therefore, we believe that we have to be open to this evidence and understand its implications regarding the modes of transmission, and also regarding the precautions that need to be taken.She added that while airborne transmission could not be ruled out in certain conditions, the evidence was not definitive and needed to continue to be gathered.Dr David Nabarro, a special envoy to the WHO on Covid-, said that while airborne transmission was certainly part of the puzzle, it is not the main route of transmission.The major way in which that this virus is transmitted is through droplets which come out when you cough, sneeze or even shout, he told the BBC Radio  Today programme.But there does seem title: amazing coastal estate stunning sea views sale
story: Stack Point House is set back from the clf edge with -degree views over Falmouth Bay, Cornwall, and direct access to the South West Coast Path.The five-bedroom property has its own headland with pasture, woodland and more than half a mile of water frontage.In the grounds are the remains of a cottage where renowned artist Henry Scott Tuke lived from  to .Sir Elton John has collected Tuke’s works since the s and was gted one by Freddie Mercury immediately before his death.In  Sir Elton loaned  Tuke pieces from his collection to an exhibition of the artist’s work in Cornwall.Estate agents Savills say the property is in one of the most scenic areas of Cornwall.The headland of Pennance Point is part of the property’s grounds and direct access to the water, including several sand and pebble coves, is possible from there.The house gets its name from the former mining stack on the headland in the mid-th century, where ores were processed and the by-products sent to Europe for title: mum revolted lizard head lidl bolognese
story: Polly Wheaton, , popped out to Lidl to buy the ingredients for a vegan spag bol for her twin daughters Isabelle and Megan, .But as Isabelle got to the final few mouthfuls on her plate, she was horried to find what looked like the scaly head of the reptile in her food.The family think it came from a jar of sauce or tin of tomatoes from the supermarket.Nail technician Polly, from Shoeburyness, Essex, said: It was traumatising - my daughter still cant eat properly after this.Its not about being vegan - nobody wants to find that in their food, whether they eat meat or not. But it did make it all the more revolting for her.I feel at the very least that this product should have been recalled. The fact that we found an exotic animal in our food in the middle of a global pandemic is shocking.But I havent had so much as a courtesy call from Lidl to apologise.Ive had to constantly chase them over the last six weeks, and all theyve told me is that their complaints team is still looking into it.I think this should take precedence over someone who has complained about a bad can of baked beans or something.Polly said the suspected lizards head was about the size of her thumbnail - which is why she had not seen it when she was pouring the ingredients into her sauce on May .She added: I dont usually shop at Lidl - during the lockdown, Ive just found it to be the most convenient and the most quiet supermarket.But I certainly wont be shopping there again.A spokesperson for the German supermarket said: We were very sorry to hear of this matter and would like to sincerely apologise for any distress that this may have caused.Following the customers initial enquiry the case was immediately raised to our Quality Assurance team who launched a thorough investigation with our suppliers.At Lidl, we pride ourselves on having thorough procedures in place to ensure that our products are of the highest possible quality for our customers.We are, therefore, disappointed that these expected high standards have not been met on this occasion.We are keeping the customer updated on the progress of this investigation, and upon its conclusion will share any results directly. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jobs brits subsidised
story: Rishi Sunak today unveiled the £billion Kickstart Scheme, which will see the Government pay towards six months of wage costs of every  to -year-old hired by employers.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe changes were announced in whats been described as a mini-Budget following the coronavirus.Heres what the Chancellor announced:It will cover  per cent of the minimum wage for a maximum of  hours a week — with firms able to top up income.The Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced the scheme in his mini-budget today as part of efforts to help Britain bounce back from the coronavirus crisis.He said: We cannot lose this generation, so, today, I’m announcing the Kickstart Scheme.A new programme to give hundreds of thousands of young people, in every region and every nation of Britain, the best possible chance of getting on and getting a job. These will be decent jobs – with a minimum of  hours per week paid at least the National Minimum Wage.And they will be good quality jobs – with employers providing Kickstarters with training and support to find a permanent job. Mr Sunak explained this meant the grant would be around £, for a -year-old, with no cap on the number of places.Other announcements included:Apprenticeships were also given a huge boost as the Chancellor announced the Government would plough in more cash for on-job training.The initiative to help boost young workers chances to getting a job after being hit hard by the coronavirus crisis will give firms £ for creating new apprenticeship roles.The scheme will also pay for businesses to take on apprentices over the age of  with a bonus of £,.Boris Johnson has put tackling youth unemployment at the top of the Government’s recovery plan. It follows dire forecasts from experts predicting more than a million youngsters will be out of work this year.The Kickstart Scheme will cost the state an average of £, for each job. But Mr Sunak hopes it will trigger a mass hiring spree by firms when it opens next month.An initial £billion has been put aside for the scheme but the Treasury said it will increase the budgetthere is high take-up.Employers will be able to offer a six-month work placement for people aged between  and  who are claiming Universal Credit and at risk of long-term unemployment.Brits are also now on track for half-price restaurant meals and cut price day trips this summer as part of a bumper plan to rescue Britains coronavirus-ravaged economy.Mr Sunak has announced a huge cut to VAT for the hospitality sector to try and get more Brits out and about to boost the nation after months in lockdown.Todays radical plans are designed to save .million jobs in the hospitality industry - which is the rd biggest employer in the UK.The Resolution Foundation last night forecast the scheme will help find jobs for around , youngsters in that age group.Research shows  to -year-olds are twice as likely to have been furloughed while , more under-s are claiming jobless benefits since March.Economic growth plunged by  per cent in April alone, but the Bank of England now believes a quick “V-shaped” recovery is likely.Unemployment is expected to soar to the highest level since the s and by May the number claiming jobless benefits had already hit almost three million.The Treasury said the jobs created by the scheme will give young people the opportunity to develop skills and experience that will improve their chances of going on to find long-term sustainable work. While the UK labour market is starting to show signs of improvement, our data shows there are three times as many people applying to every role compared to this time last year, and people in the hardest hit industries are already turning to other sectors to find jobs.Workers union the TUC insisted far more was needed.TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady said: “Mass unemployment is now the biggest threat facing the UK, as shown by the thousands of job losses at British Airways, Airbus and where. story: The actor is accused of holding the Yorkshire terrier, Pistol, out of the moving vehicle as he smoked a cigarette.He is then said to have made howling noises while travelling in the car with Heard, her sister Whitney,a driver and assistant Nathan Holmes.The shocking claim was made at the High Court today, where Depp is suing The Sun for referring to him as a we beater in a  article.Sasha Wass QC, representing The Sun, said: When you were in the car, you were smoking and you opened the window and you were angry and you were aggressive, rather like you were in that clip we saw yesterday - the monster side of your character.And you took hold of Pistol and you held her out of the window and started making howling noises.The actor responded: I can say it is a very endearing image, but it is absolute utter falsity, it is fraudulent.Ms Wass then suggested Depp thought this was funny, to which he responded: No maam, I dont think hanging an animal, a small defenceless dog that weighs three pounds out of a window is fun.Depp was also said to have later laughed at a running joke about putting the pooch in a microwave.He said: I wouldnt say that I was the inventor of that particular joke and also I wasnt the only one who brought anything like that up.The Pirates of the Caribbean star was also grilled during his evidence about an incident where the tiny pooch had eaten some hash, some cannabis - quite a lot.Depp admitted: The puppy got a hold of a little ball of hashish and just scooped it up before I could get to it.The star has been accused of being a serial domestic abuser who would lash out at Heard when he was on drink and drugs.But continuing his evidence today, Depp called the allegations a hoax.Depp was yesterday accused of turning his rage and frustration on Heard, , when he failed to control his drug and alcohol abuse.He descended into physically destructive behaviour - causing him to refer to his drunken and violent persona as the monster, it was said.Depp has brought separate libel proceedings against Heard in the US.The couple married in LA in  after meeting on the set of comedy The Rum Diary.But they orced two years later after Heard, who donated her £.million settlement to charity, accused Depp of abuse.If you are affected by domestic abuse, please call the National Domestic Abuse Helpline on   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dishy rishi sunak laid out
story: NewsopinionDishy Rishi Sunak has laid out a plan to be Prime Minister. He doesnt realise hes the Labour Partys best weaponHe talks like Gordon Brown, is as tightfisted as George Osborne, and is as likely to upset the Tory faithful as the Duke of Yorks address bookShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL Newsopinion" %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailClose your eyes, and picture an ethnic minority politician offering a job to everyone under , an environmental overhaul, and a £ shopping tree to every adult.Sounds like a socialist, right  Possibly central European, or a South American populist. Itaposs not the sort of thing a Tory from Southampton is likely to say. Nor an ex-Goldman Sachs banker. Nor an Oxbridge graduate. And probably not the son-in-law of a billionaire. Rishi Sunak is all those things, and yet said exactly that. If you think Keir Starmer is a Tory, then just imagine how the local Conservative Association chairwoman feels about the taxpayer buying Yeezys for the oiks.  It is perhaps an indication of how odd Boris Johnsonaposs government is that his Chancellor can announce such Corbynist measures to cheers from backbenchers and the Tory press. And itaposs not all due to the emergency socialism of the coronavirus crisis - after all, itaposs hard to imagine George Osborne, in the same situation, funding so much as a free slice of cake, never mind  cakes a head.But then, we live in a world where Prince Andrew apparently socialises with Denise Welch. Weaposre not so much through the looking glass, as dangling upside down from the light fittings while Johnny Depp calls us names.How you spend your £ voucher will say everything about you. Half a pound of white truffles, in the hope the price rises  A chest freezer, for future stockpiling  Or clothes, or food, or vinyl, or some alloys for the Fiesta But it would be a safe bet that Rishi wonapost bother to claim his, and will bother to ensure we hear about it. Because there is no better way to position yourself as the replacement for Boris Johnson, than a conspicuous display of humility. Rishi is already the most popular member of the Cabinet. He is considered by polls to be leaps and bounds ahead of the PM in his handling of the crisis, which just goes to show how little of it he handled.Rishi was not in charge of care homes when tens of thousands of residents were wilfully infected with a disease which was more likely to kill them than anyone . He was not in charge of PPE purchases or distribution. Nor was the late decision to lockdown, the continued shaking of hands, the confused and deathly public messaging, his problem.Perhaps most importantly, he has not said what Johnson did today: I take full responsibility for what has happened. But... All Rishi had to do was look competent, find the cash, and stay away from anything heaposd have to issue a non-apology for. Heaposs managed all three. Now all he has to do is wait.  He could wait for Johnson to implode, or for the inquiry, or the Russia report, or a local election wipeout. He may wait for Michael Gove to wield the blade, or to see how much of the human cost Johnson leaves on Matt Hancockaposs desk. But he probably expects enough of those things will happen inside the next  months to clear the way for a move from No Downing Street to No. There are few other contenders for the role. Jeremy Hunt, who lost out to Johnson last year, has sunk without trace. Gove is too closely linked with Johnson, and as Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster was one of those giving bad advice to the PM during the crisis. Hancock, Sajid Javid and a host of other potential rivals are floundering. Rishi is the best theyaposve got. Unfortunately, much like Rishiaposs budget plans, itaposs almost certainly not going to be enough.A tiny £bn for six-month work placements on minimum wage for those aged  to  wonapost get the expected million-plus people off the dole. The minimum wage for a -year-old is just £. an hour, and a huge chunk of those facing unemployment are older, have families, or are nearing retirement. Another £bn of vouchers for green home improvements will seed jobs, but % of homes in this country have a gas-fired boiler. Insulation, or a more efficient new boiler, is an improvement, but whataposs needed is affordable, reliable hydrogen-powered boilers that generate electricity too. Theyaposre available in other countries, but in the UK thereaposs no way to get one for domestic use. Despite the government working with industry, itaposs not expected for at least a decade - £bn would speed that up considerably. But perhaps the best policy of all is £m to aposgreenapos Britainaposs below-par social housing stock with insulation, heat pumps, and double glazing. In , there were m social homes in the UK.Thataposs £ a house. Rishiaposs problem is that he is positioning himself, by spending comparitively little money, to be PM ahead of a likely second, winter wave of death, in which he would again be asked to find cash for furlough schemes, tax breaks, grants and bailouts. Heaposll need to properly fund the NHS for the first winter in a decade, compensate the pantomime industry and be held personally responsible for the tight-fistedness of Father Christmas by a generation of children.Heaposs further bedevilled by an independent Bank of England, which may vote to buy government bonds, or alter interest rates, in defiance of his wishes.And then thereaposs Keir Starmer, the most efficient , popular-in-the-polls, and purposeful Opposition leader in  years. Heaposs longer in tooth and claw than the soft-palmed, inexperienced Rishi. And he is bound to point out, repeatedly, that the last government which offered a stamp duty holiday, a New Deal-style programme of public works to create jobs, and combined it with £bn of quantative easing, was Gordon Brownaposs during the financial crisis of  .

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailChancellor Rishi Sunak has unveiled a jobs, jobs, jobs package worth up to £bn to help the UK in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. The top Tory admitted the fight for the economy is only just starting as he gave a statement to Parliament today. Stamp Duty is slashed, everyone will get a restaurant discount in August, and homeowners will get £, vouchers to make their properties greener. Pubs, hotels and zoos will also be cheaper as VAT is slashed from % to % - though not on alcohol. And employers will get a £, bonus for not sacking people when the furlough scheme.   The Chancellor said: “I will never accept unemployment as an unavoidable outcome. “We haven’t done everything we’ve done so far just to step back now and say ‘job done’. “In truth, the job has only just begun.” But Labouraposs Shadow Chancellor Anneliese Dodds slammed the government for failing to extend the furlough scheme - which will end on October . Hereaposs everything you need to know from todayaposs mini-Budget. Everyone gets % off in restaurants - between Monday and Wednesday in August. And not for booze  Diners will get % off their meal at restaurants across the UK through August in a state-funded discount scheme. Eat Out to Help Out entitles every diner to a % discount, up to £ a head, at any participating restaurant, café, pub or food service establishment in the UK. The discount can be used at unlimited times, but only Monday to Wednesday, in August, and on eat-in meals including non-alcoholic drinks. You can go on multiple occasions as many times as you like - it’s just limited to £ discount per person per visit. But alcoholic drinks arenapost included. Inidual firms will register on a government website and apply to claim the money back, based on what they sell. The scheme is forecast to cost the Treasury £m. The Chancellor said it would help people find the new balance between safety and normality. The restaurants discount scheme - which can benefit , firms - is for eat-in food only and doesnapost apply to takeaways. If a sandwich shop decides to create an eat-in area i.e. put tables out, it can give the discount - but onlyyou eat in. Officials say there will be a database where people can look up participating restaurants, cafes or pubs. Guidance on the Eat Out scheme will be published on July  and the portal is due to open for firms to participate on the same day. That guidance will address whether it can be used in conjunction with other offers. Britainaposs ailing hospitality industry will be given a £.bn boost by slashing VAT from % to % on food, accommodation and attractions. The cut will come into force from July  and last until January  - making a trip to the pub or a family day out cheaper. It will apply to supplies of food and non-alcoholic drinks from restaurants, pubs, bars, cafés and similar premises across the UK. It will also apply to supplies of accommodation and admission to attractions across the UK. Further guidance is due shortly. Stamp Duty for homebuyers is being slashed - immediately  Right now there is no Stamp Duty on house purchases below £,. Today, effective immediately, the government is increasing the threshold to £,. The £.bn policy will be a temporary cut running until March  next year. The Chancellor claimed the average bill for people buying a home will fall by £,. And nearly nine of  people buying a main home this year will pay no Stamp Duty at all, he said. Unlike other measures it will benefit wealthier people - as cheaper homes had only a small Stamp Duty bill anyway. But Mr Sunak said: House prices have fallen for the first time in eight years and uncertainty abounds in the market - a market we need to be thriving. Officials said they were moved to act after Savills predicted the market would only get back to February levels by autumn . The Stamp Duty cut will take effect from midnight tonight and last until March . The rates of tax once you’re above £, stand as they were before. In other words, Stamp Duty will be charged at % on every pound from £, to £,, and %, then %, on higher amounts over that threshold. So a £, house will cost £, rather than £, in Stamp Duty. A Treasury spokesman said it was “absolutely % not the case” that the cut was brought forward because plans to do it in the autumn leaked out. The Chancellor announced a new “jobs retention bonus” in a bid to get people back off furlough and into their job. But there won’t be a cash bonus for the people on furlough themselves. Instead their employers will get a £, bonusthey bring someone back off furlough - and employ them continuously until January. To qualy, employees must be paid at least £ a month on average in each month from November to January - the equivalent of the lower earnings limit in National Insurance. If every furloughed job takes advantage of the scheme it will pay out £bn. Mr Sunak said: “Our message to business is clear -you stand by your workers, we will stand by you.” The £, bonus applies to anyone who’s previously been furloughed. More detail is expected by the end of July but full guidance is only due in the Autumn. Government officials insisted it would disproportionately help lower-paid workers keep their jobs, because £, is bigger compared to the cost of keeping them on. But it is thought thereaposs nothing legally to stop firms claiming the bonus, then making people redundant on February . But furlough is still being scrapped in October  The Chancellor stood by his decision to scrap the furlough scheme - which has subsidised more than million jobs - on October . He said “I know when furlough ends it will be a dficult moment but the scheme “cannot and should not go on forever” He said “calling for endless extensions to furlough it just as irresponsible” as ending it immediately would’ve been in June. And it“gives people  hope that it will always be possible toto the jobs they had before”, he said. If people spend longer on furlough, he said, “skills will fade” and they will “find it harder” to get new opportunities. Hundreds of thousands of young people will get six-month job placements  The package includes £billion to subsidise thousands of six-month work placements for people facing long-term unemployment.Under the “kick-start” scheme,  to -year-olds on Universal Credit will be eligible for six-month placements with the state covering % of the minimum wage for  hours a week. Bosses, who can top up wages, get a £, admin fee plus the other costs of employing someone like National Insurance. The Resolution Foundation said the scheme could help up to , young into work – but must be delivered quickly. Paul Johnson of the IFS think tank said: “There are risks of course that you will take on a  year old, and  and  year olds who you might otherwise have taken on might suffer “You might be creating jobs that are’t really jobs, pushing other people out of work. Fuller guidance is promised towards the end of July or start of August to explain how the Kickstart scheme will work. Government officials said Kickstart jobs must be genuinely new, not just replacing better-paid staff. Checks will involve checkingfirms have discussed existing or future recruitment with unions. Officials will also look at whether there have been recent redundancies,jobs were already advertised or planned to advertise, andthe posts are dferent to previous vacancies. The Chancellor pledged an extra £billion to the Department for Work and Pensionsas it doubles the number of work coaches for Universal Credit. The benefit system has been inundated with more than million claims since the start of the pandemic. The money breaks down as:£m to double the number of work coaches in Jobcentres across Britain by March  £m to expand the Work and Health Programme with additional voluntary support this autumn for those unemployed for more than three months £m to the private sector to launch a job finding support service in autumn - with one-to-one help for those unemployed for less than three months £m for the Flexible Support Fund to help claimants by removing barriers to work, such as travel expenses for attending interviews.A bonus for companies who employ trainees More than £ million is to be invested in traineeships for - year olds in response to the coronavirus crisis.Businesses offering new traineeships in England will receive a £, bonus per trainee under the £ million scheme. Firms will be paid £, to hire apprentices until January

The country stands on the brink of a devastating recession that would bring with it unemployment, poverty and despair. If we are to avoid that fate, the Chancellor must come up with an ambitious rescue package that works for the whole country. The promise of support to help young people find work is a welcome step. So too is the extra investment in the green economy. But there is an urgent need for action for those who stand to lose their jobs as the furlough scheme is wound down. Many of these jobs could be savedthe Chancellor kept the Job Retention Scheme for the sectors worst affected by Covid-, such as aviation, retail and hospitality. He should also use this opportunity to raise wages for our heroic key workers. And there must be more to help our high streets as they emerge from the lockdown. The Government was too slow to respond to the medical crisis. It must not make the same mistake with the economic emergency. If Mr Sunak fails to rise to the challenge, the price will be another generation blighted by unemployment and deprivation. Ban fur cruelty  There are not many industries more abhorrent than the fur trade. Fur farming has been banned in the UK since  but almost £million worth of pelts are still imported each year. Now we have left the EU, the Government can easily ban these imports. Our demand for action has the support of animal rights campaigners, opposition parties and celebrities. There is no place for fur in British shops. A dippy idea

It included a aposkickstartapos scheme to get young people into work and a scheme to protect the jobs of people ing from furlough. And there was a discount offer for meals out - as well as a VAT cut aimed at takeaways and attractions. The Chancelloraposs statement included some eye-catching initiatives but are they enough given the scale of the crisis  Here is what he said and the action he could have taken: What he said: “People need to know we will do all we can to give everyone the opportunity of good and secure work. People need to know that although hardship lies ahead, no one will be left without hope.” What is missing: The measures announced by the Chancellor amount to £billion – .% of UK GDP. By contrast France has unveiled a post-Covid stimulus worth €billionand Germany € billion– % of the countryaposs GDP. There was no additional support for the aviation, transport or automotive industries despite the large number of workers they employ. What he said: “Furlough has been a leline for millions, supporting people and businesses to protect jobs. But it cannot and should not go on forever.” “We’re introducing a new policy to reward and incentivise employers who successfully bring furloughed staff back – a new Jobs Retention Bonus.”  What is missing: Everyone accepts the furlough scheme needs to be wound down but Sunak has ignored calls for it to be extended for the sectors such as aviation and retail which have been worst hit by coronavirus. The £, payment for each furloughed worker firms keep on may not workcompanies bank the money for staff they were going to retain anyway and still make others redundant.It also creates a clf-edge when the scheme ends in January for workers in precarious jobs. A cut in National Insurance Contributions may have been more effective. What he said: “The Kickstart Scheme will directly pay employers to create new jobs for any  to -year-old at risk of long-term unemployment.  These will be decent jobs – with a minimum of  hours per week paid at least the National Minimum Wage.”  What is missing: This is a welcome announcement that is modelled on Labouraposs Job Protection Scheme axed by the Tories. The key will be ensuring these are decent jobs and making sure firms do not hire young people on the cheap, while laying off long-serving staff.What he said: “Right now, there is no stamp duty on transactions below £,. Today, I am increasing the threshold to half a million pounds.”  What is missing: Stamp duty cuts have long been a Tory priority but this temporary holiday may have only a limited impact on boosting the economy or helping people onto the housing ladder.The Office for Budget Responsibility has previously noted the main gainers from stamp duty cuts “are people who already own property, not the first-time buyers.”There was nothing in the Chancelloraposs statement on building more social housing or helping renters despite the fact that , tenants face being booted out when the Covid ban on evictions comes to an end on August . What he said: “At the moment, VAT on hospitality and tourism is charged at %.So I’ve decided, for the next six months, to cut VAT on food, accommodation and attractions.”  What is missing: The VAT cut will be welcomed by firms who have struggled during lockdown but it does not apply to retail which has been one of the worst hit sectors.Nor was there any support for businesses which remain under lockdown such as gyms, beauty salons, nightclubs, conference centres and bowling alleys.Labour fears that encouraging more people to meet in social gatherings could lead to a further spike in the virus when the Governmentaposs Test and Trace system is still not fully operational. What he said: “To get customers back into restaurants, cafes and pubs, and protect the . million people who work in them I can announce today that, for the month of August, we will give everyone in the country an Eat Out to Help Out discount.”  What is missing: The meal deal will be for just  days in August and will apply to hot food outlets, but not sandwich bars and takeaways.The bigger issue is why the Chancellor thinks it is a priority to help people eat out rather than those who cannot afford to put food on their table.The Trussell Trust, the countryaposs largest foodbank provider, has reported an % increase in demand during the pandemic, while the Office for National Statistics has found .% say they have struggled to pay their bills since the Covid crisis began.

Anxiety-ridden teenager Ellis Battersby had been missing for more than  hours when his body was found by school friend Fiona Passingham and her mum near their home, the coroner heard. The -year-old had struggled to cope after moving from the Great Marlow school to a college in Henley-on-Thames and as his exams drew closer he disappeared following a regular day in class. In a statement, Fiona said: I often gave Ellis a lt to school. On February  I had been out with my family celebrating my mumaposs birthday when Tommessaged me askingI had seen Ellis. I said I had not because I did not go to college on Wednesdays. At .am, police knocked on my door and told me they had found a suicide note which had my name in it. I was so worried about Ellis that at .am we went out to search for him in his favourite spots. It was cold and snowing, I expected to see him huddled in the corner shivering. We saw Ellis from afar and it looked like he was standing. The coroner heard that in , Dr Samantha Watts - a GP from Marlow Medical Group - confirmed that Ellis was diagnosed with autistic spectrum disorder and anxiety. In his last appointment in September , Ellis had explained he was increasingly anxious following his move to Henley College but was still meeting his friends on Fridays and speaking to them online. Dr Watts said: Ellis was a young man whose autistic spectrum disorder and with anxiety was exacerbated by school and exams, despite support. His state much improved at the end of exams in .  During the Buckinghamshire inquest, coroner Crispin Butler heard from Henley College counsellor Emma Holmes who had supported the schoolboy since the move. Ellis had a safe space to go to when he found lessons dficult. He had support from a teaching assistant and to one-to-one sessions with me. We did not have concerns for his safety. However, Ellis did not feel he would be able to get a job, learn to drive or be independent. The coroner explained to Ellisapos father and uncle sat in the inquest in Beaconsfield his decision that the boy, from Marlow Bottom, Buckinghamshire, had taken his own le. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mother with cancer has celebrated her last aposChristmas Dayapos after coronavirus fears delayed her making a visit to hospital.Mum-of-four Stacey Matthews, , celebrated surrounded by her children after plucking up the courage to have a scan before being diagnosed with stage four breast cancer. Stacey Matthews, , mistook her cancer for a bad back caused by her mattress - and brushed off her worries. The Blackpool mum eventually plucked up the courage to go to hospital, where an MRI scan revealed the cancer had spread to her left lung, liver, groin and spine. Further investigations also revealed Stacey had a lump in her left breast. Stacey started chemotherapy immediately in a bid to prolong her le, but after two rounds she was given the devastating news it was too late for the treatment to work and she has just weeks to live. Heartbroken at the thought of not making it to December, Stacey told family members she wanted just one last Christmas with her children Caitlan, , Byron, , Chardanai, , and Lilly, six. Local charity The Albert Project, founded by Wayne Sanderson, heard about Staceyaposs last wish and got to work immediately. They sourced donations of presents, Christmas decorations, a turkey, pigs in blankets, Christmas crackers and games from Morrisons supermarket. Other locals and businesses rallied around to give Staceyaposs last Christmas one to remember - decorating the house with lights, tinsel, and Christmas trees.  Staceyaposs four children had no idea about the plans until they arrived home to find the house transformed into a Christmas grotto and presents piled up in the living room. Full-time mum Stacey said: When the consultant told me the chemotherapy wasnapost working and I didnapost have long left, the first thing I thought about was Christmas. Christmas is a big deal in our house, having four children means itaposs always a day filled with so much happiness, and I knew I just wanted one more Christmas Day with the kids - evenitaposs in the middle of summer. My family appealed to the Albert Project and within a matter of days we were sent presents, decorations, cakes and sweets. It was just overwhelming. Iaposve been honest with the children about my diagnosis. They know I havenapost got long left and we have had some sad days, but weaposre trying to make every day a happy day from now on. I want them to have happy memories of our last few weeks together.  Seeing the kidsapos faces when they came home and found Christmas Day in the middle of summer is something I will never forget. The look on their faces was amazing, but it was very emotional at times too. At one point Lilly asked why we were having Christmas Day, and I had to tell her it was because mummy didnapost have long left and I might not be here at Christmas. It was so hard having to tell her again and the realisation hitting me. We cried a lot. Despite suffering from back pain for weeks, Stacey never thought it was anything serious and was reluctant to visit the hospital due to the virus epidemic.Stacey said: I had back pain for weeks, but I was worried about going to hospital because of coronavirus.I didnapost think it was anything serious at first, I just put it down to my bed or my mattress. I thought I might be sleeping funny, or I thought it might be something to do with my periods, but it turned out the cancer had basically crushed my spine. Iaposd also been sick quite a lot, I couldnapost keep anything down and I lost about a stone in weight, but I didnapost put two and two together. I thought I just had a stomach bug. The thought of cancer didnapost cross my mind.  By the time I went to hospital I was in agony. The consultant told me the cancer had spread and my spinal wall had collapsed, and I was given strong pain medication straightaway, and soon after I started chemotherapy and radiotherapy, but it was too late. Wayne Sanderson, from The Albert Project, said: As soon as we heard about Stacey and her family we wanted to do everything we could to help them. Under normal circumstances we are a homeless charity, but during the coronavirus crisis we have adapted to help anyone in need, and weaposve built up some amazing contacts in the local area, so we knew we could give Stacey and her family the Christmas Day they deserve in such heartbreaking circumstances.

Dean was thought to have died without making a will, so his £millon share of the farm went to his -year-old mum. Marlene Brunt in turn handed it to her eldest child, Dale, . But after Venetia discovered the existence of two wills made by her brother in , a family feud was sparked. Venetia and her uncle Bob Wrangle took up arms against Dale and the siblingsapos mum. One of the wills formed crucial evidence of Deanaposs intention to give his sister half his wealth, according to lawyers. But it was unearthed when a solicitoraposs cat knocked over a pile of papers which were about to be shredded. At the High Court in London this week, Judge Paul Teverson this week rejected claims by Dale and his mum that the wills were forged. Judge Teverson ruled that Venetia will get half of Deanaposs share of the farm.  The court heard that the three siblings inherited the farm, at Broxbourne, from their grandfather Arthur Nicholls, who had bought it with his earnings as a prize fighter. He died in . Arthur was Deanaposs hero and it was his grandfather who persuaded him to train as mechanic. Deanaposs own father, a jockey and racehorse trainer, played no part in his upbringing, the judge said. Dean, who the judge said was the gentler of the two brothers, had been starved of oxygen at birth and was thought to have suffered from learning dficulties and mental health issues in later le. A coroner ed an accidental death verdict after his body was found on a railway line near Sawbridgeworth, Herts, in . Following his death, his mum Marlene obtained letters of administration over his estate on the basis that he had died an intestate batchelor, without having made a valid will and with no children of his own.  She inherited his share of the farm and passed on that share to Dale, meaning he then owned two thirds of the land and business, which is estimated to be worth £m, and Venetia the rest. But the family fell out, with Venetia, who lives in a house on the family land, accusing her brother Dale of bullying her out of running the business and treating their -year-old uncle Winston aposBobapos Wrangle badly by trying to force him from his home, which is also on the farm. Venetia told the court she had assumed that, after Deanaposs death, she and Dale were joint owners of the farm and business partnership. And she was shocked when, nearly a decade later, her mum revealed that it was she who inherited Deanaposs share because he had not made a will, and then given it all to Dale. Then in , Deanaposs former legal adviser Howard Day discovered what he said was Deanaposs final will among his files, which backed Venetiaaposs claim to half the £m. Mr Wrangle, who helped bring up Venetia and was close to the family, took the case to court after the discovery of the will signed on Deanaposs behalf by Mr Day.  Dale and Marlene claimed that document was a forgery, made after Deanaposs death. Mr Day died last year before the issue could be settled. But the court heard that in February this year a second will in the same terms was unwittingly discovered by the solicitoraposs cat among the pile of Mr Dayaposs documents waiting to be shredded. Barrister Duncan Macpherson, for Mr Wrangle, told how the crucial second will was discovered following Mr Dayaposs death and only weeks before the case was due in court. Papers relating to disputes within the family had been sent from Mr Dayaposs office to the office of Mr Wrangleaposs solicitor, Katy Sillett, in London. Mrs Sillett was organising the papers and had piled up un-needed duplicate copies ready to be destroyed, Mr Macpherson told the judge. Her cat knocked over the papers for shredding, he continued.  When Mrs Sillett picked them up, she realised that what she believed was a duplicate will was in fact an original. Mr Macpherson said it was agreed that the second will was written at the same time as the first and so it was crucial evidence in support of the authenticity of both. It had a more steady-handed signature than the other document, which weakened claims from Dale and his mum that they were forgeries. Under the two identical wills, Dale and Venetia would share Deanaposs £m slice of the farm, rather than Dale taking it all as he ultimately wouldhis brother had died intestate. However, Dale and his mum claimed that the documents, both dated , were not valid and that they suspected they had actually been made years later after Deanaposs death. Mr Day had signed the wills on Deanaposs behalf, the court was told, but the signature on the first document to be found was unsteady. That suggested that it had been signed years later when Mr Day was less firm. Although experts said there was evidence both may have been written later, the signature on the second document found due to the cat was more steady-handed and more similar to examples of Mr Dayaposs signature of the late s. Ruling in favour of the wills, Judge Teverson said there was a substantial amount of evidence that Dean had talked in the late s about having made a will. He had told friends he had done what his grandfather would have wanted, leaving his share of the farm to his brother and sister, with his mum getting nothing. And the judge rejected the suggestions that Mr Dayaposs notes of the time when the wills were made were part of an elaborate fraud. The judge said he had no doubt but that Mr Wrangle genuinely believes Dean left behind a will and said Venetia was an impressive witness who had been genuinely shocked to learn she had not inherited Deanaposs share of the farm. I do not think she would for one moment associate herself with a fraudulent claim, he said. However, Dale appeared to be intent principally on arguing his and Marleneaposs case and his mother was a most unimpressive witness, he continued. She and Dale had deliberately kept Venetia and Mr Wrangle in the dark about Dean having died intestate and his share having gone to Dale, he found. I heard and saw Marlene give evidence. She denied ever having seen the will when a copy of it was shown to her. Her evidence then shted to saying that the document was Howardaposs will and not Deanaposs will. The court must have sympathy for and respect her grief at the loss of her son. That cannot however justy concealing from her family apart from Dale that Deanaposs estate was being administered under intestacy, which I find that she did. He said the most likely explanation was that Marlene knew there was a will, but chose not to reveal it after her sonaposs death because she thought it was not Deanaposs will but a will done by Howard Day.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWomen spend the equivalent of almost an entire month of the year worrying - and more than half admit it has an impact on their health. A study of , adults found women spend an average of almost two hours-a-day feeling worried or stressed, with two thirds of this time spent feeling anxious about other people rather than themselves. In comparison, men spend just an hour-and-a-half worrying each day, with almost one in  admitting none of that time is spent thinking of others. Almost two thirdsof women have periods where they feel constantly worried, with whataposs going on in the world at the moment - including the pandemic, protests and fears about the economy - the biggest concern. But the health of loved ones, their familyaposs safety and needing to care for older parents is also causing them to feel stressed. It also emerged women are around twice as likely to worry about their childrenaposs or grandchildrenaposs diets, health, education and future than men are. Worryingly,  per cent of those polled, by supplement brand Healthspan, admitted this leads to them neglecting their own health over fears about how it would affect their family. And a staggering  per cent of women have dismissed worrying health symptoms, simply putting them down to stress or tiredness instead. Chartered psychologist Dr Meg Arroll, on behalf of Healthspan, said: Because womenaposs stress response is all about the apostend-and-befriendapos, rather than the classic fight-or-flight, women will quite naturally worry about their loved ones. Womenaposs role in our speciesapos survival is to take care of others, so when thereaposs constant disturbing news headlines, competing caring responsibilities or concerns over putting food on the table, itaposs not surprising that stress levels skyrocket.  Managing all these competing demands often results in high levels of stress which exhibits itself in behaviours such as comfort eating, poor sleep and anxiety. This is why self-care is so very important - remember the old adage put your oxygen mask on first before helping others. This can be achieved by managing stress through techniques such as relaxation exercises and spending time in nature, eating well and adhering to a regular sleep routine. Thereaposs growing evidence that products which include CBDoil may help to tackle anxiety-related disorders, which impact our ability to fall and stay asleep. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman has reportedly been fired from her job after she was filmed telling a Black Lives Matter protester that white lives are better. The woman, identied locally as Sonya Holt, has been recorded repeatedly chanting white lives matter at a rally in Elizabethtown, Tennessee, US. Video footage has emerged of the shocking incident which local reports say led to Sonya being sacked from her job.The footage, shared on Twitter, shows Sonya surrounded by a large crowd of people and dressed in an orange top emblazoned with the words “Tennessee volunteers” and a pair of black sunglasses.As she leans against a railing, Sonya yells at the female recording the video white lives matter you black, twisted, crazy person. Sonya then responds with: What are you going to do  What are you going to do  You can run and cry. At this point, the older man, dressed in a blue top and an army cap, tells the woman filming the video: Don’t tell her s**t. Sonya is filmed mocking the woman filming the video, telling her: White lives matter, you’re just a poor little black girl who has got a messed up mind. She then begins chanting over and over: White lives matter, white lives matter.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA street dog who lost her nose when she was hit by a train has finally found a loving home after being rescued by an animal welfare charity. Moaca, an -month-old street dog from Romania, was only a few months old when she was struck by a train and left for dead. The poor pups face took the full force of the train, causing her to lose her snout, as well as a toe on one of her paws. The German shepherd and husky mix was found in the nick of time and rushed to surgery by the Nomad Vet Association who managed to save her le during a five-hour touch and go operation. However, she was left without a snout. The charity feared that she would not survive the harsh Romanian winter.Luckily for Moaca her story was uploaded online which immediately drew a kind-hearted soul who wanted to give her a loving home Joel Wareman, -year-old, from Zoetermeer in the Netherlands, said: “I found Moaca on an online Marketplace.” “To be very honest when I first saw her pictures I had to laugh and I thought what kind of a pug is this” “Then I read her story and I burst into tears because I had ridiculed her” “Her story was so sad and I immediately messaged the site telling them that I had to have her” “I had contact with a Dutch spokesperson online and he arranged the transport from Romania to Holland” “It was a smooth process and she arrived two and a half weeks later and we got to celebrate Christmas and New years eve together.”  “Moaca is the first dog I have rescued.” Despite her horric start in le, Moaca, meaning “little face” in Romanian, is not in pain although her injuries make certain tasks more dficult. “She makes a lot of mess when she eats and drinks and she can’t pick up little things but she can do everything ” Joel tell us.Joel has been fundraising on her own website Moacale in the hopes of getting a prosthetic snout for Moaca and to raise money for the charity that ultimately saved her le.“I have a lot of contact with her rescuers and I always send them pictures and videos and sometimes they come to visit her.

But one family canapost work outtheir toddleraposs creepy night time fears are based on bad dreams orthereaposs more to them. The young boy claims heaposs been seeing a strange lady in his room each night - and she makes a rather bizarre request.The childaposs grandma is so concerned about the tales of the ghostly figure that sheaposs even written into an advice column for some help on what to do next. In a letter to slateaposs Dear Care and Feeding, titled My Grandson Is Visited by a Spooky Lady Every Night, the unnamed woman explained all and we have to admit, the whole thing does sound like something from a scary movie.She wrote: My .-year-old grandson has been having a recurring nightmare for the past week and a half. He wakes up very upset saying there is a lady in his room. When askedshe talks to him and why he thinks she is there, he says that she has to get something from his room, and she wants to put something on his foot. He is afraid to go to bed. My daughter is in the process of potty training him, and he also has a new sister . I know that these le changes can cause children to have nightmares, and I understand that imagination is vivid at this age. However, this just seems so specic and kind of creepy. She adds that the family are at a loss over how to handle the situation. The agony aunt replies, stating that a week and a half isnapost a tremendously long period of time for a recurring nightmare, so the family should see how it goes for a while and possibly put the breaks on potty training for now. Additionally, the writer suggests trying all the common nightmare remedies - such as sleeping with a night light and using a weird lady spray that renders any weird ladies harmless. If all  fails, they recommend buying a nanny cam so we can all see the ghost.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailNASA has released images of Storm Edouard as it transforms into a tropical cyclone.The UK is set to be hammered by wind and rain from the powerful weather front moving across the Atlantic.Met Office forecasters says two massive lumps of cloud could bring days of showers for some. Images of Edouard from space show it gathering pace and growing as it northeasrward. According to the National Hurricane Centre, the cyclone is forecast to continue moving rapidly before it is expected to be absorbed into a larger front over the North Atlantic today. NASA said the cyclone was officially born on July  and is the fth tropical storm of the Atlantic Ocean this hurricane season. National Hurricane Center forecaster Jack Beven noted, “The cyclone is located in a region of strong southwesterly vertical wind shear, is heading for colder water, and is approaching a frontal system.  This combination should lead to extratropical transition between  to  hours, and it is possible that Edouard could strengthen a little as transition occurs.  After transition, the extratropical low should persist for another  hours or so before the circulation dissipates.” While Edouard will considerably be less powerful by the time it hits Britain, forecasters are warning of plenty of unsettled weather to come.Met Office forecaster Aidan McGivern said the worst of the weather will be seen in Wales before the weekend with mm plus in some of the more exposed spots.Temperatures once again held back because of the cloud and outbreaks of rain, he continued. National Resources Wales has placed two flood alerts in place, as a result. BBC meteorologist Tomascz Schafernaker agreed Britain is going to be left particularly soggy with outbreaks of rain to hang around for  hours or so. However, he said the weekendaposs looking pretty good with lots of warm sunshine on the way - and some forecasters predict the UK could see seven days of heat next week.

title: a more sane sober and serene world
story: In July , the eyes of the world turned upon Scotland as global leaders arrived in Gleneagles to focus on matters of worldwide signicance.The United Kingdom was a dferent place.At Westminster, Labour had just secured a third term with Tony Blair at the helm and continued to make poverty-reducing levels of investment nationally and debt-cancelling levels of estment internationally.At Holyrood, the Scottish Labour Party was in the middle of a second term as the governing party of Scotland.I have been reflecting on how things have changed and, without seeking to be overly nostalgic, it felt a more sane, sober and serene world.Days before the G summit, about , men, women and children marched in Edinburgh to “Make Poverty History”.During the G summit, the first major Islamic terrorist attack took place on British soil.And, not long after the G summit, the wheels began to come off the British, European and global economy, which was a historical turning point.Poverty is no longer global but local, terrorism is no longer international but intranational and our economy is no longer mildly beleaguered but entirely broken. title: dundee holidaymakers rush to book foreign getaways this summer
story: Fears that lockdown would dash dreams of a holiday abroad this summer have been cast aside by Dundee holidaymakers.Hays Travel, which reopened its Dundee branch on June , report a surge in bookings from customers keen to grab a week in the sun.Branch manager John Stewart told the Tele: “We were pleasantly surprised. We’d been taking bookings on the phone during lockdown but at % of normal levels.“On the first day open we were exceptionally busy. We had four desks operating at the branch and had to call on extra help to cope with the numbers coming in.“In that first week we took as much bookings as the Thomas Cook branch did in the whole of July last year.”By far the favourite destination for Dundee holidaymakers was Spain, he revealed, followed by the Canary Islands and Turkey.With air travel rules yet to be finalised in Scotland, customers were prepared to fly from Newcastle and Manchester airports to guarantee a holiday abroad.England has lted quarantine restrictions for holidaymakers travelling to a list of  ‘air bridged’ countries, but Nicola Sturgeon branded the plan ‘shambolic’.Scottish airport bosses this week called for clarity “as soon as possible” to prevent further job losses and allow routes to be re-established.John commented: “We’re just awaiting an announcement from Nicola Sturgeon which we expect will bring another upturn in demand.#He added: “I’ve been in the travel industry for  years and been through the twin towers, wars in the Middle East – so many global events – but one thing is for certain, the tourism industry is resilient.”While most travel agent branches are now open for business in Dundee, Barrhead Travel – which announced redundancies this week – is currently closed.A spokeswoman for the Glasgow-based firm told the Tele the Dundee branch is expected to open again in the next fortnight.She added: “Our commitment to supporting our customers is not affected by this announcement – we have teams still working remotely and we’re contacting all customers who have bookings affected by Covid- disruptions.“We can assure all of our customers that their holidays remain fully financially protected.”The firm – which employs  staff in  branches throughout Scotland – said the dficult decision to make staff redundant came as a direct result of the impact of Covid-.Jacqueline Dobson, president of Barrhead Travel, said: “Customer confidence has been dented by the ongoing uncertainty surrounding quarantine and travel restrictions.#This, combined with the imminent closure of the furlough scheme, means we have had to announce a number of redundancies.“We will be ensuring that there is full support available for all our colleagues – personally and professionally – over the coming months.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including title: dundee united micky mellon tranmere
story: New boss Micky Mellon says he couldn’t turn down the opportunity to manage a ‘fantastic club’ like Dundee United.Mellon signed a two-year deal at Tannadice on Monday after United paid Tranmere Rovers compensation for his services.In a farewell message to Tranmere supporters, gaffer Mellon admitted the draw of ing home to Scotland was too big.The former Fleetwood Town and Shrewsbury manager also believes the challenge of replacing Robbie Neilson, who departed for Hearts last month, is something ‘really special’ for him to take on.The -year-old said: “I need people to understand how big a decision it was for me because I think anybody who knows me, knows what a fantastic time I had at Tranmere, how much I loved and enjoyed it there.“I just felt the opportunity came to do something I’ve always wanted to do and that’s manage in Scotland and be up among my family and at a fantastic club like Dundee United.“It was going to be something that made me think. It was going to take something really special for me to want to take it on.“That doesn’t make my feelings for Tranmere in any way any dferent. It’ll always be a special place for me and it’ll always be the one of the first results I look for.“I had such a great time and it’ll certainly be somewhere I miss very much.”LEE WILKIE: Micky Mellon less of a gamble for Dundee United than Steve McClaren" title"#LEE WILKIE: Micky Mellon less of a gamble for Dundee United than Steve McClaren# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-micky-mellon-less-of-a-gamble-for-dundee-united-than-steve-mcclaren embed # secretwoHBwbS" data-secret"woHBwbS" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"After a rigorous search, which saw the Tangerines court the likes of Tommy Wright, Steve McClaren and Malky Mackay, Mellon’s appointment has been met with widespread approval by supporters.United fans’ group ArabTRUST say they are delighted to have the Scot in the manager’s office next season, believing the club are once again on a sound footing.In a statement they said: “ArabTRUST is delighted with the appointment of Micky Mellon as first-team manager of Dundee United.“There are many reasons to be optimistic as a Dundee United supporter at this moment in time – Arabs are ing to back the club in droves, we have a fantastic infrastructure, heritage and supportive American ownership that has a track record of investment in United.“We also have many fine young players making the break through into our first team.”The group, founded in , is one of the largest shareholders in the club. It works closely with United in youth development and many other community initiatives.Stuart Campbell sits on the Tannadice board as associate director representing ArabTRUST and the fans in general.He was impressed by the quality of person applying for the manager’s role but insists Mellon was the standout candidate.#I am delighted that Micky has agreed to become first-team manager at Dundee United,” he said.“From a long list of impressive applications, he was the outstanding candidate.“We look forward to an exciting season ahead with Micky at the helm and can only hope that Arabs will be given the green light to fill Tannadice soon to roar on the team.”ArabTRUST chair, Susan Batten, added: “The conditions are in place for Micky Mellon to succeed and all Arabs will be desperate for him to do so – he will receive our full backing.#LEE WILKIE: Micky Mellon less of a gamble for Dundee United than Steve McClaren" title"#LEE WILKIE: Micky Mellon less of a gamble for Dundee United than Steve McClaren# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-micky-mellon-less-of-a-gamble-for-dundee-united-than-steve-mcclaren embed # secretwoHBwbS" data-secret"woHBwbS" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: lee wilkie micky mellon less of a gamble for dundee united than steve mcclaren
story: I’ll admit I don’t know too much about Dundee United’s new manager Micky Mellon.However, I do think he’s much less of a gamble than someone like Steve McClaren would have been for the Tangerines.I’m in the same boat as everyone  right now, trying to find out what I can about the new boss at Tannadice.What I have seen gives me encouragement that he can be a success at United.For all his experience, McClaren won’t know much about Scottish football and there have been a number of clubs where things just haven’t worked out for him.Mellon, though, has an impressive win-rate down south and has won promotions with three dferent clubs.What encourages me most about him is the way a number of his former players have spoken about him.Interviews have been complimentary but what struck me is they all said much the same thing – he respects his players, works hard for them and his man-management is very good.From what I’ve read, he sounds like someone you’d want to play for.And that’s exactly what United need right now.He’s also said himself that he doesn’t have a particular style as a manager – he adapts the style of the team to the players he has at his disposal.I think he said it was like walking into a pub, seeing  blokes and making a team out of them, not knowing what you are going to get.That shows he backs himself to get the best out of the players and sounds like the right fit for the Tangerines right now.With the way United are structured with a sporting director in Tony Asghar, that sounds like someone who can cope well with that sort of set-up.And signing somebody like Jamie Vardy for Fleetwood shows he’s got an eye for a player as well.With the fixtures out now and games on the horizon, I am glad United have got Mellon in.I do think it dragged a little, it’s been more than two weeks since Robbie Neilson left for Hearts.Asghar said there was no rush and maybe taking that bit of extra time will make all the dference in getting the right man in.However, it does feel like there’s very little time for the new man to really get to grips with the squad before the kick-off on August .That’s just three full weeks of preparation and getting to know his new players.It’s a tight turnaround but I’m excited to see United back in action.He’s still pretty young at -years-old but it says a lot about Jordan McGhee that he’s been chosen as Dundee’s new captain.Josh Meekings departed last week at the end of his contract, leaving the skipper role vacant.Experienced midfielder Paul McGowan was named vice-captain but for the club to give responsibility of the armband to a relatively young defender shows the faith they have in him.He evidently has the respect of his fellow players, too.If he didn’t, there would be no way manager James McPake would choose him to lead his team out when football restarts for Dundee in a few months.As with every player, there is room for improvement and the Dee boss obviously sees McGhee as key to the immediate future for his side.Ideally, I’d like to see an experienced centre-back in next to him for the new campaign to really push him on.However, it looks like it’ll be McGhee and Jordon Forster –those two start the new season well, Dundee might not need to replace Christophe Berra.What a change it is at Manchester United these days – after years of struggles, they look like a proper team again.They way they have been going since bringing in Bruno Fernandes, I’d back them to snap up a top-four spot.Looking dangerous and full of goals, it just shows how one signing can make the dference.Since the Portuguese arrived, Man U have gone up several gears and are great to watch again, finally.Dundee United have every right to feel incensed by the ongoing legal wrangle with Hearts and Partick.The money it has cost them to defend themselves is tough to take not to mention taking a bit of the shine off their title triumph.Dundee United set to launch joint crowdfunding campaign title: family support charity to benefit from aberdeen parade collection fund
story: A charity which supports vulnerable families with young children has been chosen as the recipient of the Celebrate Aberdeen Parade Collection Fund.Home-Start Aberdeen will use the £, donation, collected by volunteers with buckets during the  parade, to continue supporting struggling families who have been impacted by Covid- and the resulting lockdown.Home-Start’s team of trained volunteers normally support families through weekly home visits.The money will allow the charity to provide  “create and cook” packs, containing food ingredients, recipe books and crafting materials, to help families build their confidence in cooking.Eleanor McEwan, Home-Start Aberdeen’s general manager, said: “It means a huge amount to us to be chosen to receive this year’s funding from Celebrate Aberdeen to help with our vital work supporting families all across Aberdeen.“We’ve taken part in every parade since the first one in  and it’s always a great experience for our families, volunteers and staff.”Last year  organisations and , marchers took part in the parade. All participating organisations were invited to bid for the £, donation.Both the Celebrate Aberdeen Parade and the Celebrate Aberdeen Awards have been cancelled this year due to the coronavirus pandemic but willin .Katie Aldred-Dow, Celebrate Aberdeen parade manager, said: “Every year we receive exceptional applications for the parade fund and it’s always very dficult to choose just one.“We are delighted that Home-Start has been chosen as this year’s recipient.“The work they do goes a long way towards supporting young families through what have been extremely challenging and traumatic times, and the skills they are teaching will have a long-term benefit.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: full list all the aberdeen bars offering free pints tennents
story: Tennents will be raising a glass to Aberdeen residents by buying them a pint.Complimentary pints of Tennents Lager and Tennent#s Light will be waiting for people in the north-east to enjoy at licensed premises.Bars, restaurants, hotels and sports clubs in Aberdeen including The Illicit Still, Soul Bar and No. Bar and Restaurant have signed up and are looking forward to serving their customers pints of the beer soon.It forms part of Tennent#s Dedicated to You campaign which will bring together friends and families after months of absence.Drinkers can claim their complimentary pint at TennentsdedicatedtoyouThey can also share the campaign with someone close to them to allow them to sign up to get a fresh quality pint in one of the thousands of participating bars.Kenny Gray, Managing Director at Tennent’s, said: “For the last  years, Tennent’s Lager has been dedicated to Scotland and proud to serve the freshest, quality pints to pubs and drinkers across the country.#From moments with friends and family to birthdays, holidays, anniversaries and graduations – the list of things we’ve all missed during this dficult period is endless # and we know that going to the pub ranks highly.#After work drinks, cosy pub lunches and memorable nights out with friends have all been put on hold for nearly four long months.“But we can now finally look forward to celebrating these important milestones once again while creating new ones and what better way to welcome everyone back than by dedicating a pint of Tennent’s Lager or Tennent’s Light to Scotland.”A video has been created showcasing this new campaign:The list of Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire pubs is here, although not all have reopened yet:For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - title: web aberdeen cinema reaches 25k fundraising target
story: An independent cinema in Aberdeen has announced that it has reached its £, fundraising goal to help it reopen after the Covid- lockdown.The news was announced in a video posted to the cinema#s Twitter account by manager Colin Farquhar.In the video, he said: #Thank you so much to everyone who#s donated.#It#s been unbelievable the response #you#ve liked, shared posts, thank you so much for spreading the word.#I want to particularly say thank you to our members and our audience.#I know the wider community have been really involved, but our membership have responded in the most unbelievable way with people making amazing donations, making the kindest comments on social media and writing the most wonderful wee letters.#The fundraiser for the cinema, located on Belmont Street, was set up online on June  and asked people to donate £ # the price of a membership # or whatever they could.The description on the GoFundMe page said: #We’ve now had no real income for more than  months and we anticipate that as well as a reduction in admissions when we do re-open, due to constraints on capacity in the building and changing habits of customers, we will have to invest hard cash into making the building safe and navigable for our customers and staff.#Even with the support we have been able to access from Creative Scotland, Aberdeen City Council, Scottish Government and the UK Government through the furlough scheme which has helped with the immediate financial strain, we know that when we reopen there will continue to be dficulties to make ends meet.#Belmont Filmhouse isn’t just a cinema.
